tools/gate/00_setup.sh.message: It's a principle that the roles in this repository must be executable on their own. If we install netaddr here, then we will not be able to use the sushy roles without running this script, which may be removed in the future. Could we add this in the ansible itself?
Why do you use pip? Why not apt? Like I have in my abandoned one: https://review.opendev.org/726903

It doesn't matter which way to install, ansible should have an ability to import netaddr package in python code, both options works - pip and apt. From the docs [1]

"To use this filter in Ansible, you need to install the netaddr Python library on a computer on which you use Ansible (it is not required on remote hosts). It can usually be installed with either your system package manager or using pip"

Since it's ansible dependency it will make more sense to add it to the line within ansible installation part.

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_filters_ipaddr.html
Ok, I got it. Thanks. One small suggestion: maybe it's better to use one var to define a list of packages and provide it for apt with/without proxy as a var name to remove duplication.

This is actually a correct place for this package. Netaddr is required by ansible plugin, which is executed on the ansible controller. Whatever you install in playbooks, is installed on remote host against which role is executed, so for example if we are running role on remote host, and not localhost, adding it in playbook will not help. This should be a prerequisite for ansible installation itself, not the playbook.

> This is actually a correct place for this package. Netaddr is
 > required by ansible plugin, which is executed on the ansible
 > controller. Whatever you install in playbooks, is installed on
 > remote host against which role is executed, so for example if we
 > are running role on remote host, and not localhost, adding it in
 > playbook will not help. This should be a prerequisite for ansible
 > installation itself, not the playbook.

Thanks for the explanation. This makes sense

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Also storing information in the weigher between scheduling attempts is wrong. Each scheduling attempt needs to be independent from any previous one.

There was one semantic change that I was unsure about. Previously if the Weigher defined a min/max value and a weight was smaller / bigger than that then the min/max value was changed according to the weight. Now the weight is always forced to be between the min/max defined by the Weigher.

But then reading the doc of minval/maxval the intention is that the weight of an object never go out of this range. And the current implementation just forces that properly.
Yeah, this is an additional feature, rather than a bug fix as such. But without it, I can see a bug where would need this feature to fix that bug. OK I have lost myself there, but hey.

nova/tests/unit/scheduler/weights/test_w.message: Double checked and if I remove the bugfix then the second run of the weigher is influenced by the first run.

nova/weights.py.message: Idea example of de-coupling, these would all be changed from self.minval and self.maxval to self.dynamic_minval and self.dynamic_maxval

@melanie witt
This is to my understanding the exact same functionality you propose to have for "dynamic_minval" already built into "normalize()" if we pass "None" for minval or maxval. No need to compute it again in "weigh_objects()".
I think we broke this at some point, in theory each run should have its own instance of the weigher... I need to go check the history here.

That's at least not how the code worked previously. It only updated the max value of a single weigher with all the objects in a run - not across mulitple weighers. So in the end, we computed the max value of all objects a weigher has ever seen since last restart. But still confined to a single weigher, so different weighers could have different maxval.

The "dynamic_maxval" you propose, if kept at the point where I removed the code for saving the max value on the weigher, would also only save the maximum value of a single weigher's objects. If we clear it after each run, that's equivalent to the code in normalize, as you described:
> this logic you underlined will only find the max value of all objects being considered by a single weigher

Well, what I was thinking is that the idea of the existing self.maxval "saving" the value every time was that it finds the max value of all objects across all of the weighers.

This logic you underlined will only find the max value of all objects being considered by a single weigher. This maxval will not incorporate the maxval of previous weighers [in a single run].

With the "dynamic_maxval" we would be able to bump up our max value based on what each weigher sees, so by the time the last weigher runs, it would normalize based on the latest max value.

The problem as I understand it is that the "saved" maxval doesn't get cleared out after each scheduling run, so that it is a fresh start for a new scheduling run.

Does that make sense?

Guh, I see now -- only each weigher saved a min/max. Sorry about that. Thanks for being patient about it.

Hm. I guess that proves that I still don't understand why the original code made a point of saving a running min/max of everything since last restart.

I had a look at the review that originally added the minval/maxval logic [1] to learn how it was intended to be used (warning, it is very old).

Here's a quote of a comment by Hans Lindgren:

"If I have a weigher for a resource that ranges between 1 and 100 and normalize the weights of two objects, the normalization will produce equal results for weights that differ on the scale (as long as the same object has the highest weight).

For weights [0, 1], this will result in normalized values [0.0, 1.0].
For weights [99, 100] this will still result in the same [0.0, 1.0].

Lets assume I have two objects and two weighers. Both weighers produce values in the same range (this could possibly be already normalized values like utilization of resources which range from 0.0 to 1.0). The weighers give weights [0.1, 0.2] and [1.0, 0.1] which without further normalization gives final weights [1.1, 0.3]. With the current way of calculating normalization, the result will instead be [1.0, 1.0] which has an effect on the ordering of the objects."

The code previous to this patch was gleaning the minval and maxval from the min and max the weigher sees as it considers objects, if it has not been set by the weigher class itself. I checked the in-tree weighers and found a few set minval, none set maxval, and most set neither.

This means that mostly the minval and maxval is calculated on-the-fly across all weighers in a run, based on what object values it sees (which makes sense to me).

Based on this, I'm thinking we probably don't want to remove this functionality entirely right? Given the issue presented by Hans years ago. This change would remove all of the consideration of the min and max values in a set of objects across weighers at the normalize() step because the normalize() call is only passed self.minval and self.maxval.

So, I'm wondering if we could instead do something like de-couple the "configured" minval and maxval from the dynamically calculated minval and maxval and reset self.dynamic_minval and self.dynamic_maxval to None after each full run of weighers, so that previous runs don't influence future runs? Or maybe someone else has a better idea?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/27160
really sorry, I have just spotted I have a follow up comment I never pubished here :(

Your quoted comment has some example computation. Let's add some more specificas to that: The two weighers both don't set maxval, but set minval to 0 - which is what the current in-tree weighers do. Imho, [0.1, 0.2] and [1.0, 0.1] returned by the weighers would then result in "normalize()" computing values of [0.5, 1.0] and [1.0, 0.1] which gives a result of [1.5, 1.1]. So something has changed to whatever Hans saw. Probably best seen in the sentence, which I believe doesn't hold true today

 > For weights [99, 100] this will result in the same [0.0, 1.0]

As the changes here don't break any of the already existing test, we just had to add one to actually show the problem with the code, I'm pretty confident that it should still work similar to before.

I think the fix might actually to store a minval and maxval for just this set of objects.

I think its because we now cache the weigher objects, I need to go read the history a bit...

If we store the minval/maxval for this set of objects, then we could

1) compute it later, too. That's whats implemented in "normalize()" already via "max(weight_list)".

2) would in the implementation chosen before not adhere to the minval/maxval set by the weigher, i.e. overwrite explicitly set minvals

So I think this code stopped working as intended after this change:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/c126d36640e0398e76ba01783b7f21f01f53a5f5

We always used to create a weigher object for each host list. I belive the original intent here was to avoid looping over the weights to determine the min and max. Although my memory around talking to SandyW/comstud about this is getting very hazy indeed. I am 99% sure that is a nonsese premature optimization (just like the quota reservation system we took out).

Your code is changing things somewhat here... you are ensuring the limits are within what the weigher object as set as its minval and maxval. Now I think that is probably a noop for all the intree code, as the min_value = 0 weighers always have a min_value of 0, etc.

All that aside, I think your code does restore the intended normalization behaviour, and also adds the feature of checking something claiming a min_value is 0 doesn't start returning negative values.

normalize() called with only self.minval and self.maxval

With the idea example, this would be like:

 minval=weigher.minval or weigher.dynamic_minval
 maxval=weigher.maxval or weigher.dynamic_maxval
This would have to check for `None` instead of just `or`, if we use it. Because most `minval` are set to `0`.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/do.message: could there ever be cases where both verify paths are valid?  This will prioritize the SYSTEM_CERT_PATH

The verify path points to a list of trusted CAs so as long as one matches, then everything is fine. Technically it is possible to have both verify paths as valid, but unlikely. I prioritized the SYSTEM_CERT_PATH because I feel like users will likely install their own registry certificate (either signed by a well known CA or their own CA but then add that CA to the trusted list through "system certificate-install", which puts it in SYSTEM_CERT_PATH) as opposed to using the default self-signed one. Prioritizing this way makes the average use case send 1 request as opposed to 2.
same width comments in this file.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message:
more of a nit than anything.
log.exception automatically includes the entire exception information and stacktrace  so   log.exception("Failed to get docker registry catalog")  might be more informative.
Do we include the info about the image that fails in any of these failure logs, or in the attempts so a person troubleshooting will know which ones to examine.

Since the image name/tag is available here, and in the other new exception handling, it would be nice to have:
Failed to delete docker registry image X

No we don't log the specific image that failed, although these exceptions should be generic enough that they apply to all images (we are not throwing exceptions for image not found, for example). I'm pretty sure you can dig them out of the sysinv or bash logs if you really want to though...

openstackclient/identity/v3/project.py.message:
This breaks when I test it locally because it's already operating on a boolean.

 (py36) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack project create --property is_domain=True my_domain                                                                             
'bool' object has no attribute 'lower'

We can avoid the issue by using an elif statement.

http://paste.openstack.org/raw/793621/

I've proposed what I needed to do to get this passing in a subsequent patch. Feel free to incorporate it into this patch if you'd like.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/728320/1

This is because the kwargs dictionary is being reused.

When I test this, I'm passing is_domain=True, which invokes the first case and overwrites the kwargs to be a boolean instead of a string, causing the second if statement to fail.

I think the current test is only passing because it's being tested with is_doamin=false. If we add a test for is_domain=true, this statement would fail because we're expecting to operate on a string but we actually have a boolean.

What the relationship between this changed and bug?

If some of the shares that doesn't belong to manila share or some other reasons, the share name doesn't named "****share**", it will enter this branch and raise error. In this case, we don't need to care about other shares, the result that we expected is success.  Could you explain it?

If some of the shares that doesn't belong to manila share or some other reasons, the share name doesn't named "****share**", it will enter this branch and raise error. In this case, we don't need to care about other shares, the result that we expected is success.  Could you explain it?

The for cycle block parses the output of smbstatus regardless the name of the share. The regexp match fails only if the output of smbstatus is broken/unexpected. This should be reported into log rather than fail silently.

python/drydock_provisioner/drivers/node/.message: The variable `link` was previously defined - the renaming of `l` to `link` changed the behavior of this block.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Great!!
Do you have any numbers as to how long does for the indeces to be created?

Also, what's the memory cost?

The indexes themselves are created empty, so super fast. :) Then it is just a matter of inserting new objects in sorted order. For an overview of performance, see: http://www.grantjenks.com/docs/sortedcontainers/performance.html. We use SortedKeyList.

At our size, the answer is that the index overhead in speed is negligible.

Memory-wise, since we are already storing the objects in memory, this *should* just be the overhead of storing a list of reference pointers per index.

Maybe for users to tailor this we need the numbers above or perhaps some recommendation? Looks like this could use a small doc section (follow up patch maybe) and a release note as it seems like a *big improvement*.
++ people need to hear about it!

Yeah, I'd like to see some browbeat testing for real-world numbers. Even on small DBs like running neutron tempest tests like `tox -e dsvm-functional ovn` shaves a couple of minutes of the runtime for me. Things like neutron-ovn-db-sync-util should be *way* faster.

Documentation is something that I started to add, but then realized "oh yeah, there's no real documentation at all" So I've added a todo item for myself this week to write some base documentation that I can add indexing documentation to. :)

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py.message:
Also note that for networking-ovn, which defines its own start_connection() to avoid the ovsdb_connection class variable scope, that this a) won't run and b) setup_indices() won't work because it accesses cls.ovsdb_connection.

Need to find a way to make all of that prettier w/o breaking the world.
Is there any cons to have this defaulting to True ?

Mostly that it is a change in behavior--so if there is a bug someone theoretically could get bitten by it (though the code defaults to a normal lookup if it is not found in index). 

Also, the change to start_connection() being an instance method and hiding the ovsdb_connection in a property due to Neutron overriding the Backend. I need to test whether neutron will croak w/ it starting out enabled.

The other thing is if users of the library wanted to be more limited in what they index, since indexing isn't free.

Maybe default to True in master and to False in stable backports?

Maybe a stupid question because I don't know exactly how it works under the hood, but what if there is a schema change and we have new column?

The new index will be created? What about the old one?
Cool! Thanks for the explanation!
If there's a schema change, we're restarting, and since all of this is in-memory, index is gone.
Yeah, I don't know either. Are those in memory ? If so I think we are fine cos reconnections will happen once the db is upgraded
I think it's safer to put these two to "else" block to limit the scope of ValueError on index_create only
Good point, will do.
Is it possible that `table` will not be in `tables` if you get tables in L67?
++ ok
table can be removed in L82. This way we don't try to create an index for a table that already had one created via lookup_table.
ditto
will do.
Went ahead and made this default for master

I moved this out of the try/except KeyError: pass due to a failing Neutron functional test that made me realize that this was silly. if you do a lookup(table, UUID(...)), you are very obviously looking up by UUID in that table. Lookups by name, etc. will never have a UUID type, so continuing to look for them is silly in addition to the fact that if a UUID is passed to the indexing code it will try to compare that uuid to the column type, which is not going to be a UUID and it will throw an exception.

this almost feels like it belongs to a separate gerrit.
but that is just a nit comment. I say that because it steals
the thunder from the awesome indexing funtionality being added.
no worries. I think it is fine as is.

I went back and forth on it. On one hand, it isn't required for indexing to work on ovsdbapp. But it is required for indexing to be able to work on neutron with it's overridden start_connection  etc. In the end, I went with simplicity for reviewing/merging instead of what, I agree, would be technically better.
is there a place that uses this? I'm having a hard time finding it. If not, maybe we need a unit test for it?

Yeah, it is there for the case of custom indexes/users who don't use auto_index=True. It absolutely should have tests--god call. I'll probably add a functional test for it since requires actual tables/rows/interaction with python-ovs and I kind of hate all of the FakeTable/FakeRow stuff of unit tests when the functional tests suite runs everything in under 10s anyway. :D
assuming this is something users may use to leverage indexing, maybe add a short description on how this is expected to be used?

These are now required for this patch because testing create_index() required them due to ovsdb_connection already being set up sometimes with indexing. So I lucked out re: having an excuse for not putting it in a separate patch. :D
nit: this feels like a method that should be "private" (quotes due to how encapsulation works in python :D)
Yeah, that makes sense.
nit: It's kinda hard to understand the logic here, perhaps a brief comment explaining these conditions would be helpful for those reading the code.

That's what the comment below was trying to do, but yeah, probably from too high a level...the lookup_table semantics are super weird and confusing and need to be documented. It's basically a table that the various ctl CLI tools use to map up things like "look up this row in this table by an index or by this column in another table" etc. *Most* things are simple "you can look this up by the name column." And for now, those are the only cases we care about.

It was kind of a hold-over from when we had the vsctl backend because we wanted the arguments to match the ovs-vsctl lookups and for a very few tables we needed the lookup_table. Now it's mostly "Logical_Switch doesn't define an index for 'name', so add it so api.lookup() works for name lookups for Logical_Switch". QoS can be looked up from the Port.qos, SSL table via Open_vSwitch.ssl, etc.

The (very basic) docs from where the logic was copied in OVS is here: https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/8508a57228560e154963c542823d36d8098e6610/lib/db-ctl-base.h#L252

I'll make sure that that gets documented in a followup documentation patch.

Moving this out of the other try/except because of a neutron test failure that exposed that passing a UUID() object when looking up by uuid or an index means you are really definitely looking for UUID--index columns aren't ever UUIDs (they may be strings representing UUIDs, but never an actual UUID object).

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/idlutils.py.message: Maybe a TypeError or something more specific here is safer?

uuid.UUID() can raise all kinds of errors ("bob" would do ValueError, 1234 would do AttributeError, etc.), we just pass through and raise a TypeError no matter what with the type that was passed in the Exception.

I guess I originally was thinking that info would be sufficient for debugging, but right now, since we don't try to catch any errors from _fixup_match (and it shouldn't ever return a KeyError), we could just get rid of try/except altogether and just raise whatever we get. Does that sound better?

Is there ever a case when the str from keys() change? 
I am not sure if we can expect python to consistently give the keys in the same order.

is None a valid answer? If not, we could 'blindly'
return uuid.UUID(match) and skip the 'elif' all together.
Exception expected, of course. ;)

I think you are right. I'll test it. Now there is a part of me that wants to just remove this and make people use code that passes the correct type...but I have a feeling there will be errors (surely I wrote this for a reason back in the day!).
Moved this to a separate function to facilitate testing with assert_not_called to ensure that we found the value through an index.

config_tempest/users.py.message: update the docstring for the new fallback argument

I wonder if this is an overkill or not .. i believe that in 99,99% of case there will be just one demo user in the system prior tempestconf execution.

Maybe it would be enough to create only up to 3 or 5 users - in that case:
a) we don't need to import a new library
b) we don't have possibly an endless loop
c) we won't create a new user every time we run tempestconf which could lead to quota exhaustion and etc

I bet that if there already is a demo1 user in the deployment, it was created by us :D if we create up to 3 users, the chances that demo3 was created by us are really almost 100%

OR maybe what if used a very specific name for the demo user creation, something like demo-tempestconf .. in that case we can be sure such a user is not in the system pre-created and if it's already there, it was created by us (the issue with creating as many users as we run tempestconf will be solved)

vmware_nsxlib/v3/config.py.message: pep8: E303 too many blank lines (2)

perhaps this could be another configurable parameters, defaulting at 100/sec. This just for handling the situation where we need adaptive rate limiting but we also never want to exceed a specific max rate

param api_rate_limit_per_endpoint is used as the max rate in adaptive rate mode. If we pass in (api_rate_limit_per_endpoint=40, api_rate_mode='AIMD'), API rate will start at 1/s and will never exceed 40/s. 100/s is the hard limit in case user specifies a value that is too large.

vmware_nsxlib/v3/utils.py.message: pep8: W391 blank line at end of file
Why not use adjust_rate here, and define adjust_rate as "pass" in base class?
OK. Forgot to change when breaking into two classes with inheritance.
just curious, should we also enforce a hard limit in the base class too?

I'm sorry but whenever I see a lock I can't resist asking:
1) how would that impact client request processing at scale
2) can we avoid it

I believe the impact at scale should be minimal as threads spend a negligible amount of time in the critical section. Do you agre with this view?

On another note, do we really need it? Looks like we only need to know if the "signal counters" are positive, so even if we end up having concurrent updates it should be ok - we might however need to change the logic for resetting the signals.


(we can also use compare-and-swap but given the expected concurrency level I think the impact will be much worse than the lock due to retries)

Specifically it would look like:

now = time.time()
if now - self._last_adjust_rate >= self._period:
  with self._lock:
    if now - self._last_adjust_rate >= self._period:
      continue from L761

Not sure if there's better ways for this redundant condition check through

I think it could be optimized as follows:
- Bypass locking at L753 for adding counts for signals
- Add lock between L760 and L761. This would reduce the need for locks to only adjust_rate calls close to period cut-offs
- Check again for condition at L760 after acquire lock, to guarantee that the rate to be changed only once per period.

What's your idea on this one?
so negative take precedence over positive if both > 0?

Yes, as negative signals are generally solid proof of congestion, where positive signals usually only hints that we may have the extra bandwidth to increase window size.

This is the same in TCP where within RTT even if all but one packet is ACKed we still decrease the cwnd.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: Why do we need a proxy here? Why can't self.instance_running_pool simply be the eventlet.GreenPool?

We already have a proxy-function in place for the same reason: nova.utils.spawn_n
>     This utility exists so that it can be stubbed for testing without
>    interfering with the service spawns.
IMO making test fallout smaller is not a good reason to put a proxy class in place. That's taking "test-driven development" too far :P

Because otherwise we end up with a lot of broken unit/functional tests - that way we can make use of SpawnIsSynchronousFixture and proxy the calls to spawn_n and return _FakeGreenThread. And since we are using the pool in build_and_run_instance a lot of tests are broken.

Okay, thanks for the explanation, I understand the need to be able to mock this pool independently of others.

I suspected the whole PoolProxy class was overkill, though, so I tried this [1], which seems to work fine. Feel free to smash that in here (though you should rename it InstanceRunningPool or similar, because it's no longer a proxy; and include a docstring describing why it's needed).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672299/
You have no testing for this, I could remove it and nothing would fail.

This is described in the commit message and yes you can.

You mean oslo services' graceful_shutdown_timeout config?

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.service/latest/configuration/index.html#DEFAULT.graceful_shutdown_timeout
So, this limits the number of parallel builds that can start so that we can watch them and wait...

However, this was added to do half of that... Limit the number of parallel builds. With the config you've added, the two now interact with each other. Further, the semaphore isn't really needed at all if we bound the number by a dedicated pool. So perhaps we should remove the semaphore, replace it with the pool, and initialize the pool size from the existing max_concurrent_builds config to avoid people having to change their configs and/or know about both?

If this route is taken the wait would happen without the instance being locked. Wouldn't that be an issue?
As per your comment in _locked_do_build_and_run_instance:
# NOTE(danms): We grab the semaphore with the instance uuid
# locked because we could wait in line to build this instance
# for a while and we want to make sure that nothing else tries
# to do anything with this instance while we wait.
I'm not sure what your point is... we can still grab the lock before grabbing a worker from your pool...
I wonder how this works as cleanup_host goes after rpcserver.stop() and by default instance requires network-instance-plugged event via RPC. Could you explain this a bit?
Not sure build_semaphore should go away if RPC is open see my prev comment.
Ok, maybe pool with a conf option is enough.

Seems the commit message should call out the related oslo.service change (which has -1s from oslo cores on it).
Shouldn't the option have min=0 then? What would -1 mean in this case? Never timeout?
(unrelated) I wonder why these thread pool size options are in [DEFAULT] rather than [compute]

How does this option relate to the max_concurrent_builds option? The help text should explain that because max_concurrent_builds defaults to 10 and this defaults to a random 30.

What are the side effects of setting this too low or too high? Should this be considered for different compute drivers, i.e. would anyone besides ironic or vcenter driver users ever need to configure this to a high number? And if the number is too high, what could happen? One side effect would be if you're using the vCenter driver and have this set to 1000 to accommodate the nova-compute service managing an entire cluster, then trying to stop the service could take a long time. Will systemd eventually timeout?
After the timeout all threads are killed.

Similarly, how does this related to the graceful_shutdown_timeout option which defaults to 60 seconds? If instance_spawning_pool_size is set to 1000 and graceful_shutdown_timeout isn't changed to accommodate that, what happens on stop of the service? Does it timeout and blow up anyway? Does the greenthread get killed?

This is open for suggestion - the instance_spawning_pool_size = 30. We can change to 10 if max_concurent_builds is equal to 10. I havent noticed any side effects. I am doing this for the vmware driver but should be relevant for all others - I don't see why not. This is not depending on any concrete driver implementation. Other than that I dont know if systemd will eventually force shut. The idea here is to finish all outstanding tasks.

This list format doesn't render properly:

https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_543/666245/11/check/openstack-tox-docs/5433c96/docs/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.instance_spawning_pool_size

See how it's done in the option help above.
Ok I'll fix that

You didn't address anything that I mentioned in PS11 for documenting this option. The description here doesn't really mean anything to an operator reading this - they would have to read the code to understand what effect this has, when to consider using it (lots of vms on a single host, like when using the vcenter driver), and what the consequences can be, e.g. stopping the service could take a lot longer while waiting to finish server build tasks - and that's not to mention it sounds like you haven't done testing to find out if there is eventually going to be a hard timeout from the graceful_shutdown_timeout option or systemd hard killing the service. IOW, have you done any sort of test that spawns enough VMs (or even just one and inject a sleep to make it hit this) that when stopping the service it waits at least longer than graceful_shutdown_timeout and found that things are OK?

After the timeout all tasks are stopping and the threads are killed. So it all depends from the timeout we set. So if I have 90 machines spawning - the service is going to let the outstanding tasks go for as long as the timeout duration is. After restart of the service the tasks which are not done enter in error state.
I did test the functionality, maybe not in the scale you want it - I will try to do more tests and document this better.
When
Why?

For me "After nova compute is gracefully shutdown" means that we are done with the shutdown. So at that point it is not logical to start waiting for things to finish. But I'm not native English so I will defer to another core here.
It is deployment specific if nova runs under systemd or other init system so you cannot depend on systemd's behavior in nova.
you mean servers?
Then I don't know what is the 'tasks' that will enter into ERROR state here.
I mean service.
All instances which are spawning will be in ERROR state
referring to systemd still feels bad to me, nova services could very well run under other init systems.
Ok I will remove this
